misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when performing an array shift operation, it is necessary to use a temporary variable (like `holder`) inside the loop to store the element being shifted, even when the target location (`arr_numbers[index]`) is directly assigned the value of the source location (`arr_numbers[index - 1]`). This implies a misunderstanding of direct variable assignment and array element manipulation.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java execution model handles simple assignment operations efficiently. When `arr_numbers[index] = arr_numbers[index - 1];` is executed, the value at the source index is copied directly to the destination index. Introducing an intermediate variable (`holder`) to store `arr_numbers[index - 1]` before assigning it to `arr_numbers[index]` is superfluous and demonstrates a lack of confidence or clear understanding of how array elements interact during sequential assignments.
